support_summary: The glycine-rich C-terminus of TDP-43 directly interacts with hnRNPC1/C2, as identified through proteomic approaches.

functions.cellular_process: TDP-43 and hnRNPC are both core components of the spliceosome and co-regulate the splicing of target pre-mRNAs.
functions.effect_description: TDP-43 and hnRNPC can bind to overlapping or adjacent sites on pre-mRNAs, cooperatively or competitively influencing splice site selection and exon inclusion/exclusion. This interaction is part of a broader network of hnRNPs that fine-tune the transcriptome.
biological_consequence: TDP-43/hnRNPC interaction → Co-regulation of splicing targets → Altered protein isoform ratios → Disrupted cellular function
specific_effects: Like TDP-43, hnRNPC is known to suppress cryptic exon inclusion.
The interaction contributes to the complex regulatory network governing RNA processing.

evidence.paper_title: Abnormal Splicing Events due to Loss of Nuclear Function of TDP-43: Pathophysiology and Perspectives

mechanism: TDP-43 and hnRNPC are both core components of the spliceosome and co-regulate the splicing of target pre-mRNAs.
effect: TDP-43 and hnRNPC can bind to overlapping or adjacent sites on pre-mRNAs, cooperatively or competitively influencing splice site selection and exon inclusion/exclusion. This interaction is part of a broader network of hnRNPs that fine-tune the transcriptome.
summary: TDP43 activates hnRNPC1/C2 to modulate alternative splicing, ultimately affecting disrupted cellular function.

evidence.paper_title: Abnormal Splicing Events due to Loss of Nuclear Function of TDP-43: Pathophysiology and Perspectives
